AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Nashville Sound: Jeff Brock's Music Is All Over Television
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Jeff Brock has never recorded a hit song, but people who watch TV frequently hear his music. The 39-year-old Brock is president of a ``music house,'' a company that provides tunes for TV commercials. Brock Music, his company, has won or shared five Clios or ADDYs, national awards for excellence in advertising. Some of his best-known music accompanied these spots: _ Actor Richard Farnsworth posing in a desert eating chips with the tag line, ``the flavor's a legend.'' _ Fast-food hamburger containers open their lids and talk to each other. _ A bleach with the hook line, ``Don't just get 'em clean, get 'em vivid.'' Brock provides music to advertising agencies that have contracts with major corporations. He comes up with original music or arranges a well-known song that already has been chosen for an ad. Brock, who supervises a staff of four plus several free-lance music writers and arrangers, says music is important to the overall content. ``I think music plays an immense role in the memorability of a spot. When you have 5-year-old kids running around singing jingles all day, you know it has a lot of impact on people's minds,'' he said. He estimates that 70 percent of his work is ``post scores'' _ seeing the ad without music and writing a tune to emphasize what's happening visually. ``The music is supposed to be poignant and jump out,'' Brock said. The guidelines vary. ``They will say they want something appealing to kids age 12 to young adults age 25. In that age group, you go for something hard hitting, something a little more rock 'n' roll. ``Sometimes they say they want music like ... and they name the artist. I come up with something similar to that artist or that style,'' he said. ``Sometimes we go out on a limb and say we don't think it will work and here's what we suggest. ``And in other cases, they say they have no earthly idea what they want. But they know it when they hear it. Those are the toughies. You may come up with something you think is incredibly good, but the client doesn't.'' For a recent spot about food to be taken to work, he was instructed to come up with music that sounded ``classical, English, very proper.'' ``When I wrote those scores, I wrote from an acoustical standpoint with strings and woodwinds and light, fun, British-sounding music. It came out beautifully and they are airing nationally.'' He writes some lyrics, but most of the time they are written by the ad agency. ``We sort of pick up the ball and run with it wherever they decide to pass it off to us,'' Brock said. He always knows the client, but sometimes it is top secret. ``We're not supposed to let out what we're doing or the campaign, and this can be painful because you've just done a wonderful session for someone and they are not going to break the campaign for three months and you can't even play it for anybody.'' In most cases, the spots are 30 seconds long, some only 15 seconds. ``You don't get a chance to say much in 15 seconds,'' he said. The companies and products he has worked with include General Mills, Century 21, K mart, the Walt Disney Co., CBS News, Folgers, McDonald's, Long John Silver's and Ralston Purina. Brock Music is one of about 15 Nashville companies doing music for jingles. ``Our value is our versatility,'' Brock said. ``We do all musical styles. We do a lot of different things well.'' Brock was raised in Anderson, Ind., and worked as a jingle singer in Dallas before he began writing jingles in 1975. He moved to Nashville the next year. Ten years ago he wrote the music for political advertising, including the music for Dan Quayle's first campaign for the U.S. Senate in Indiana. ``We helped to elect a lot of candidates,'' said Brock, who also was a judge in the 1989 Miss America Pageant. He turned to jingle writing because he didn't want to continue doing political ads. His office complex has a small studio in the rear where most of the ad music is created. He plays keyboards himself as needed. ``I think when you have some leeway, and the agency allows you to be creative and do the job you feel is needed for that project, and it comes out wonderful, it's very satisfying.''
